title: Black can break strings immediately after an escape

labels.name: C: invalid code
labels.description: Black destroyed a valid Python file

body:
**Describe the bug**
Black does not produce identical code if it unluckily chooses to split a regex pattern right after an escape.

**To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Given black installed via a particular git commit - accomplished via `python3 -m pip install git+git://github.com/psf/black.git@ea03b6c5e1f96aa2569f0080a61577b368b7af0d`
```
black                    19.10b1.dev118+gea03b6c
```

and a long regex string, as found in this example file foo.py:
```python
REGEX_PATTERNS = {
    "asdf_hjkl_jkl": re.compile(
        r"(?<!([0-9]\ ))(?<=(^|\ ))([A-Z]+(\ )?|[0-9](\ )|[a-z](\ )){4,7}([A-Z]|[0-9]|[a-z])($|\b)(?!(\ ?([0-9]\ )|(\.)))"
    ),
}
```

Black will error s follows:
```
python3 -m black --diff foo.py
error: cannot format foo.py: INTERNAL ERROR: Black produced invalid code: EOL while scanning string literal (<unknown>, line 3). Please report a bug on https://github.com/psf/black/issues.  This invalid output might be helpful: /var/folders/1z/64vyvtv136v6mfhfr16hws3c0000gn/T/blk_bbdmeyyx.log
Oh no! ðŸ’¥ ðŸ’” ðŸ’¥
1 file would fail to reformat.
```

The contents of that log are as follows:

```shell
% cat /var/folders/1z/64vyvtv136v6mfhfr16hws3c0000gn/T/blk_bbdmeyyx.log
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/black/__init__.py", line 6042, in assert_equivalent
    dst_ast = parse_ast(dst)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/black/__init__.py", line 5953, in parse_ast
    return ast27.parse(src)
  File "/Users/matt/Library/Python/3.7/lib/python/site-packages/typed_ast/ast27.py", line 50, in parse
    return _ast27.parse(source, filename, mode)
REGEX_PATTERNS = {
    "asdf_hjkl_jkl": re.compile(
        r"(?<!([0-9]\ ))(?<=(^|\ ))([A-Z]+(\ )?|[0-9](\ )|[a-z](\"
        r" )){4,7}([A-Z]|[0-9]|[a-z])($|\b)(?!(\ ?([0-9]\ )|(\.)))"
    ),
}
```

**Expected behavior**

Don't break strings immediately after an escape. This seems like it requires inspection of the string contents to avoid this.

**Environment:**

- Version: master
- OS and Python version: Mac OS X / python 3.7.7

**Does this bug also happen on master?** 
Yes. In fact, using https://black.now.sh/?version=master it ignores the error and produces invalid python code, which is a UI issue with that site.
